message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The CD4+ T-lymphocyte count of 162/mm3 indicates that the patient is immunocompromised and at risk for opportunistic infections. Pneumocystis jirovecii is the most common opportunistic infection in patients with HIV and a CD4+ T-lymphocyte count <200/mm3, hence prophylactic treatment against it is most appropriate.

Prophylactic treatment for Pneumocystis jirovecii with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is recommended in this situation. The other options are also opportunistic infections seen in HIV patients, but prophylactic treatment for them is not recommended at this time. Mycobacterium tuberculosis would require prophylaxis if the interferon-gamma release assay was positive.
